title: 109_hr4162
content: The Act titled "Los Padres National Forest Land Exchange Act of 2005" allows for a land exchange in Los Padres National Forest, California. The United Water Conservation District of California can exchange lands with the Secretary of Agriculture, with the District conveying its lands and receiving National Forest System lands in return. The exchange is subject to existing rights and terms specified by the Secretary. The District's lands to be conveyed are approximately 340 acres in San Bernardino base and meridian. The United Water Conservation District of California can exchange approximately 340 acres of its lands with the Secretary of Agriculture for National Forest System lands. The National Forest System lands to be conveyed by the Secretary consist of approximately 440 acres located within township 5 north, range 18 west, San Bernardino base and meridian. The United Water Conservation District of California plans to exchange 340 acres of its lands with the Secretary of Agriculture for National Forest System lands. The National Forest System lands consist of approximately 440 acres in township 5 north, range 18 west, San Bernardino base and meridian. Tracts ranging from 2.5 to 40 acres in section 15 will be exchanged, including NE1/4NW1/4, S1/2SW1/4SW1/4SE1/4, N1/2S1/2S1/2SE1/4, S1/2N1/2SW1/4SE1/4, N1/2NW1/4SW1/4SE1/4, SW1/4SE1/4, S1/2NW1/4SE1/4SE1/4, SW1/4NE1/4SE1/4SE1/4, W1/2W1/2NW1/4SE1/4, and SE1/4SW1/4NW1/4SE1/4. The United Water Conservation District of California plans to exchange 340 acres of its lands with the Secretary of Agriculture for National Forest System lands. Tracts ranging from 2.5 to 80 acres in sections 15, 22, and 27 will be exchanged. The United Water Conservation District of California plans to exchange 340 acres of its lands with the Secretary of Agriculture for National Forest System lands. Tracts ranging from 2.5 to 80 acres in sections 15, 22, and 27 will be exchanged. Tract 21 is approximately 60 acres, and Tract 22 is approximately 10 acres. The lands to be exchanged are depicted on maps titled "Los Padres National Forest Land Exchange" dated June 1, 2005. Adjustments to legal descriptions and boundaries can be made by mutual agreement. The land exchange will be processed based on equal value exchange. The land exchange will be conducted on an equal value basis as determined by appraisals. The Secretary must ensure that the title of the acquired lands complies with the Attorney General's standards. The exchange should be completed within one year of the Act's enactment. Easements and access rights will be reserved by the Secretary in the conveyance of National Forest System lands. The Secretary will reserve easements for roads and trails necessary for administrative purposes and public access to National Forest System lands. Perpetual pedestrian and equestrian access rights will be reserved over existing roads and trails. The District must construct a gravel parking area on District lands for access to the Potholes trail, subject to Secretary approval. Vehicular access may be regulated by the District. The District can regulate vehicular access to the parking area. Public lands withdrawals from previous acts are revoked for National Forest System lands. Water rights are not included in the land exchange. Cash equalization payments can be made to equalize land values for the exchange. The Secretary can receive cash equalization payments exceeding the statutory limit, which will be deposited into a specific fund for the Los Padres National Forest in California. The funds can be used for facility acquisition, construction, or improvement without further appropriation. Administrative costs are also covered. The costs of conducting the land exchange under this section shall be shared equally by the District and the Secretary, including survey, mapping, appraisals, closing costs, and recording fees. The boundaries of the Los Padres National Forest will be adjusted as a result of the land exchange, with District lands acquired by the Secretary added and administered as part of the forest. The District and the Secretary will share the costs of conducting a land exchange, including survey, mapping, appraisals, closing costs, and recording fees. The boundaries of the Los Padres National Forest will be adjusted, with District lands becoming part of the forest. The House of Representatives passed the bill on June 12, 2006.
